questions.title: Transverse wave: amplitude, wavelength and sound speed
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: Figure 1 represents a transverse wave. Which arrow represents the amplitude of the wave?
markScheme: Answer: C — Arrow C shows the **amplitude** (equilibrium to peak/trough).

parts.text: Which arrow represents the wavelength of the wave?
markScheme: Answer: B — Arrow B shows the **wavelength** (one complete cycle, peak to peak).

parts.text: A wave has a frequency of 5000 Hz. Calculate the period of the wave.
Give one example of a transverse wave that can travel through a vacuum.
markScheme: 1 mark: Any named **electromagnetic wave**, e.g. **light**, **radio waves**, **microwaves**, **infrared**, **ultraviolet**, **X-rays**, **gamma rays**.

parts.text: Figure 2 represents a longitudinal wave. Which point is at the centre of a rarefaction?
markScheme: Answer: B — Point **F** is at the centre of a rarefaction (where particles are most spread out).

parts.text: A sound wave has a frequency of 750 Hz. Speed of sound in air = 330 m/s. Calculate the wavelength of the sound wave.
Describe a method that could be used to determine the speed of sound in air.
markScheme: 1 mark: Method of making a sound, e.g. **clapping**, cymbals, starting pistol.
1 mark: Measuring the **distance** between sound source and detector (e.g. using tape measure, trundle wheel).
1 mark: Measuring the **time** for the sound to travel (e.g. stopwatch, data logger, oscilloscope).
1 mark: Using the equation $\text{speed} = \frac{\text{distance}}{\text{time}}$ (or dividing time by 2 for echo method).

questions.title: Differences between longitudinal and transverse waves
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: Waves may be longitudinal or transverse. Describe the differences between longitudinal waves and transverse waves.
markScheme: 1 mark: A wave is caused by **oscillations/vibrations**.
1 mark: For a transverse wave, oscillations are **perpendicular** to the direction of energy transfer.
1 mark: For a longitudinal wave, oscillations are **parallel** to the direction of energy transfer.

parts.text: Radio waves are electromagnetic waves. Describe how radio waves are different from sound waves.
markScheme: 1 mark: Radio waves are **transverse** (sound waves are longitudinal).
1 mark: Radio waves travel at the **speed of light** / much faster.
1 mark: Radio waves have **higher frequencies** than sound.
1 mark: Radio waves can travel through a **vacuum** (sound cannot).

questions.title: Submarine ultrasound and sea floor distance
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: Ultrasound is sound above the maximum frequency that humans can hear. What is the maximum frequency that humans can hear?

A submarine sends a pulse of ultrasound to the sea floor. The pulse takes 0.25 seconds to travel from the submarine to the sea floor. The speed of sound in water is 1600 m/s. Calculate the distance from the submarine to the sea floor.
The ultrasound is reflected from the sea floor back to the submarine. Use the correct answer from the box to complete the sentence.
segments: The total distance the ultrasound pulse travelled is
the distance to the sea floor.

parts.text: The submarine moves through the sea and every few seconds sends a pulse of ultrasound to check the distance to the sea floor. Table 1 shows the time taken for five ultrasound pulses to travel from the submarine to the sea floor. Describe how the distance from the submarine to the sea floor changed over these five pulses.
markScheme: 1 mark: From pulse 1 to pulse 3, the distance to the sea floor **decreased** (the sea got shallower / submarine went deeper).
1 mark: From pulse 3 to pulse 5, the distance to the sea floor **increased** (the sea got deeper / submarine rose).

parts.text: An electronic system produces ultrasound with a frequency of 500 kHz. What does the symbol kHz stand for?
State one industrial use for ultrasound.
markScheme: 1 mark: Any valid industrial use, e.g. **cleaning** (delicate objects), **quality control / flaw detection**, **sonar**.

parts.text: State one medical use for ultrasound.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Pre-natal scanning** (accept destruction of kidney stones or cleaning teeth).

parts.text: An ultrasound detector is connected to an oscilloscope. The diagram shows centimetre squares on an oscilloscope screen. Each horizontal division represents 2 microseconds. Calculate the time, in microseconds, between one peak of one ultrasound pulse and the peak of the next.

Ultrasound waves are partially reflected when they reach a boundary between two different media. The time taken for the reflection from the boundary to reach the detector can be seen from the oscilloscope screen. What can be calculated from this time interval?
markScheme: 1 mark: Between the **boundary and the detector/source**.

parts.text: Explain what action scientists should take if they find evidence that ultrasonic waves may be harmful to human health.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Publish / share** their evidence/results/data with doctors/the public.
1 mark: **Carry out more research/tests** to check reliability (or stop using them / restrict to industrial purposes only).

parts.text: Explain what an ultrasound wave is.
markScheme: 1 mark: With a frequency **above 20 000 Hz / 20 kHz** (above the audible range / cannot be heard by humans).

parts.text: Ultrasound waves can be used to clean jewellery. One method is to put the jewellery in a bath of cleaning fluid which contains an electronic oscillator. The electronic oscillator generates ultrasound waves in the cleaning fluid. Suggest how these waves clean the jewellery.
markScheme: 1 mark: Particles/molecules/fluid **vibrate** (or by the process of **cavitation** / formation and collapse of tiny bubbles).
1 mark: Which **knocks particles of dirt off** the jewellery / breaks up dirt from the surface.

parts.text: Ultrasound is used for pre-natal scanning. This is much safer than using X-rays. However, doctors were only sure it was safe after experiments on mice. Explain whether or not you think that these experiments were justified.
markScheme: 1 mark: A valid point, e.g. other mammals are **similar to humans** / unethical to experiment on humans / knowledge will **benefit humans**.
1 mark: An appropriate qualification/expansion, e.g. so results are appropriate / it is better to experiment on mice / ultrasound has proved **useful**.

parts.text: The diagrams show oscilloscope traces for the same musical note played on two different instruments. The oscilloscope settings are not changed. How can you tell, from the diagrams, that it is the same musical note?
How can you tell, from the diagrams, that the musical note has been played on different instruments?

Ultrasound waves are partially reflected when they meet a boundary between two different media. What does the word 'media' mean when it is used in this context?

questions.title: Loudspeaker frequency and ultrasound bolt inspection
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: The diagram shows a microphone being used to detect the output from a loudspeaker. The oscilloscope trace shows the wave pattern produced by the loudspeaker. The total time shown on the screen is 0.0001 s. How many waves are produced by the loudspeaker in 0.0001 seconds?
How many waves are produced by the loudspeaker every second? Assume the input to the loudspeaker does not change.
markScheme: 1 mark: **30 000** waves per second (3 waves in 0.0001 s → 3 / 0.0001 = 30 000).

parts.text: A person with normal hearing cannot hear the sound produced by the loudspeaker. Explain why.
markScheme: 1 mark: The frequency is **above 20 000 Hz** (the frequency is 30 000 Hz).
1 mark: This is above the **upper limit of the audible range** / it is **ultrasound**.

parts.text: The diagram shows how a very high frequency sound wave can be used to check for internal cracks in a large steel bolt. The oscilloscope trace shows that the bolt does have an internal crack. Explain what happens to produce pulse A and pulse B.
markScheme: 1 mark: The wave is **partially reflected** at the crack to produce pulse A.
1 mark: And reflected at the **end of the bolt** to produce pulse B.

parts.text: Use the information in the diagram to calculate the distance from the head of the bolt to the internal crack. The time between the transmitted pulse and pulse A on the oscilloscope is 0.000025 s (round-trip). Speed of sound through steel = 6000 m/s.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: time from diagram = $0.000\,025$ s
1 mark: Correct rearrangement: one-way time = $\frac{0.000\,025}{2} = 0.000\,012\,5$ s
